sect1.title: FAQ
sect1.para: Find solutions for the most common pitfalls here. If your problem is not mentioned here, checking the log files on either the &admserv; or the &ostack; nodes may help. A list of log files is available at .

listitem.para: Please check the script's log file at /var/log/chef/install.log for error messages.

varlistentry.term: I have configured a bastion network, but ifconfig does not show the second NIC after having run install-chef-suse.sh.

listitem.para: In order to activate the bastion network, you need to run two additional commands after having run install-chef-suse.sh:
listitem.screen: crowbar network -U crowbar -P crowbar allocate_ip default $(hostname -f) bastion admin chef-client

varlistentry.term: I have successfully set up a bastion network but cannot reach the &admserv; from outside the admin network. route -n shows no gateway for the bastion network.

listitem.para: Make sure the value for the bastion network's "router_pref": entry in /opt/dell/chef/data_bags/crowbar/bc-template-network.json is set to a lower value than the "router_pref": entry for the admin network.

varlistentry.term: Can I change the hostname of the &admserv;?

listitem.para: No, once you have run install-chef-suse.sh you cannot change the hostname anymore. Services like &crow;, &chef;, and the RabbitMQ will fail when having changed the hostname.

varlistentry.term: Browsing to the &chef; Web UI gives a Tampered with cookie error:
How can I log in to a node as &rootuser;?

listitem.para: By default you cannot directly log in to a node as &rootuser;, because the nodes were set up without a &rootuser; password. You can only log in via SSH from the &admserv;. You should be able to log in to a node with ssh root@NAME where NAME is the name (alias) of the node.

If name resolution does not work, go to the &crow; Web interface and open the Node Dashboard. Click on the name of the node and look for its admin (eth0) IP Address. Log in to that IP address via SSH as user &rootuser;.

varlistentry.term: A node refuses to boot or boots into a previous installation.

listitem.para: Make sure to change the boot order in the BIOS of the node, so that the first boot option is to boot from the network/PXE boot.

varlistentry.term: When deploying a node after having allocated it, it fails to PXE boot with the following error message: Could not find kernel image: ../suse-11.2/install/boot/x86_64/loader/linux

listitem.para: The installation repository at /srv/tftpboot/suse-11.2/install on the &admserv; has not been set up correctly to contain the &sls; 11 SP2 installation media. Please review the instructions at .

varlistentry.term: When deploying a node after having allocated it, it hangs at Unpacking initramfs during PXE boot.

listitem.para: The node probably does not have enough RAM. You need at least 2 GB RAM.

varlistentry.term: After the installation of a node has finished, it hangs at Executing AutoYast script: /var/adm/autoinstall/init.d/crowbar_join:

listitem.para: Log in to the node as &rootuser; and check the log files at /var/log/crowbar-join* for errors.

Check the &chef; client logs on the &admserv; located at /opt/dell/crowbar_framework/log/d*.log. Further information is available from the &chef; client logs located on the node(s) affected by the proposal (/var/log/chef/client.log), and also from the logs of the service that failed to be deployed. Additional information may be gained from the &crow; Web UI logs on the &admserv;. For a list of log file locations refer to .

varlistentry.term: A new hard disk installed on a node that is already deployed is ignored by &crow;

listitem.para: If adding a new harddisk to a node that already has been deployed, it cannot be used because &crow; does not see the disk.
This is caused by an error in &crow;. Issue the following commands on the &admserv; as a workaround (replace NODENAME with the the name (alias) of the node affected:
listitem.screen: crowbar crowbar transition NODENAME foo crowbar crowbar transition NODENAME ready

sect1.title: Support
sect1.para:
2012-09-07 - fs: Do we have some official text on cloud and support we could use here?
Whenever you contact support to help you with a problem on &cloud;, it is strongly recommended that you gather as much information about your system and the problem as possible. For this purpose &productname; ships with a tool called supportconfig. It gathers system information such as the current kernel version being used, the hardware, RPM database, partitions, and other items. supportconfig also collects the most important log files, making it easier for the supporters to identify and solve your problem.

It is recommended to always run supportconfig on the &admserv; as well as on the &contrnode;. If a &compnode; or a &stornode; is part of the problem, run supportconfig on the affected node as well. For details on how to run supportconfig, please refer to .
